sentence.text: TENORMIN (atenolol) tablet
TENORMIN (atenolol), a synthetic, beta1-selective (cardioselective) adrenoreceptor blocking agent
TENORMIN is contraindicated in those patients with a history of hypersensitivity to the atenolol or any of the drug product s components.

mmtx.phraseText: any of the drug product s components.

sentence.text: In patients with acute myocardial infarction, cardiac failure which is not promptly and effectively controlled by 80 mg of intravenous furosemide or equivalent therapy is a contraindication to beta-blocker treatment.

mmtx.phraseText: controlled by 80 mg of intravenous furosemide

sentence.text: As with other beta blockers, when discontinuation of TENORMIN is planned, the patients should be carefully observed and advised to limit physical activity to a minimum.
Bradycardia and heart block can occur and the left ventricular end diastolic pressure can rise when beta-blockers are administered with verapamil or diltiazem.

entity.text: left ventricular end diastolic pressure can rise

sentence.text: Because of its relative beta1 selectivity, however, TENORMIN may be used with caution in patients with bronchospastic disease who do not respond to, or cannot tolerate, other antihypertensive treatment.
Since beta1 selectivity is not absolute, the lowest possible dose of TENORMIN should be used with therapy initiated at 50 mg and a beta2-stimulating agent (bronchodilator) should be made available.

mmtx.phraseText: the lowest possible dose of TENORMIN

sentence.text: TENORMIN should be used with caution in diabetic patients if a beta-blocking agent is required.
At recommended doses TENORMIN does not potentiate insulin-induced hypoglycemia and, unlike nonselective beta blockers, does not delay recovery of blood glucose to normal levels.

Atenolol has been shown to produce a dose-related increase in embryo/fetal resorptions in rats at doses equal to or greater than 50 mg/kg/day or 25 or more times the maximum recommended human antihypertensive dose1.
Patients already on a beta blocker must be evaluated carefully before TENORMIN is administered.

mmtx.phraseText: Patients already on a beta blocker

sentence.text: Catecholamine-depleting drugs (eg, reserpine) may have an additive effect when given with beta-blocking agents.

Patients treated with TENORMIN plus a catecholamine depletor should therefore be closely observed for evidence of hypotension and/or marked bradycardia which may produce vertigo, syncope, or postural hypotension.
Calcium channel blockers may also have an additive effect when given with TENORMIN (See WARNINGS).
Disopyramide is a Type I antiarrhythmic drug with potent negative inotropic and chronotropic effects.

mmtx.phraseText: a Type I antiarrhythmic drug with potent negative inotropic

sentence.text: Disopyramide has been associated with severe bradycardia, asystole and heart failure when administered with beta blockers.
Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic agent with negative chronotropic properties that may be additive to those seen with beta blockers.

mmtx.phraseText: an antiarrhythmic agent with negative chronotropic properties

sentence.text: Beta blockers may exacerbate the rebound hypertension which can follow the withdrawal of clonidine.
If the two drugs are coadministered, the beta blocker should be withdrawn several days before the gradual withdrawal of clonidine.

mmtx.phraseText: several days before the gradual withdrawal of clonidine.

sentence.text: If replacing clonidine by beta-blocker therapy, the introduction of beta blockers should be delayed for several days after clonidine administration has stopped.
Concomitant use of prostaglandin synthase inhibiting drugs, eg, indomethacin, may decrease the hypotensive effects of beta blockers.

mmtx.phraseText: Concomitant use of prostaglandin synthase inhibiting drugs,
Concomitant use of prostaglandin synthase inhibiting drugs,
the hypotensive effects of beta blockers.

sentence.text: Information on concurrent usage of atenolol and aspirin is limited.

mmtx.phraseText: Information on concurrent usage of atenolol

sentence.text: Data from several studies, ie, TIMI-II, ISIS-2, currently do not suggest any clinical interaction between aspirin and beta blockers in the acute myocardial infarction setting.

mmtx.phraseText: beta blockers in the acute myocardial infarction setting.

sentence.text: While taking beta blockers, patients with a history of anaphylactic reaction to a variety of allergens may have a more severe reaction on repeated challenge, either accidental, diagnostic or therapeutic.
Both digitalis glycosides and beta-blockers slow atrioventricular conduction and decrease heart rate.
Concomitant use can increase the risk of bradycardia.

ellipsisSentence.text: Both digitalis glycosides and beta-blockers slow atrioventricular conduction and decrease heart rate.
Both digitalis glycosides and beta-blockers slow atrioventricular conduction and decrease heart rate.

sentence.text: Chronic studies employing oral atenolol performed in animals have revealed the occurrence of vacuolation of epithelial cells of Brunner's glands in the duodenum of both male and female dogs at all tested dose levels of atenolol (starting at 15 mg/kg/day or 7.5 times the maximum recommended human antihypertensive dose11, respectively).

mmtx.phraseText: female dogs at all tested dose levels of atenolol

sentence.text: Atenolol is excreted in human breast milk at a ratio of 1.5 to 6.8 when compared to the concentration in plasma.
The initial dose of TENORMIN is 50 mg given as one tablet a day either alone or added to diuretic therapy.
TENORMIN may be used alone or concomitantly with other antihypertensive agents including thiazide-type diuretics, hydralazine, prazosin, and alpha-methyldopa.
Injection in Dextrose Injection USP, Sodium Chloride Injection USP, or Sodium Chloride and Dextrose Injection may be used.

Data from other beta blocker trials suggest that if there is any question concerning the use of IV beta blocker or clinical estimate that there is a contraindication, the IV beta blocker may be eliminated and patients fulfilling the safety criteria may be given TENORMIN Tablets 50 mg twice daily or 100 mg once a day for at least seven days (if the IV dosing is excluded).

mmtx.phraseText: Data from other beta blocker trials
the use of IV beta blocker

sentence.text: Although the demonstration of efficacy of TENORMIN is based entirely on data from the first seven postinfarction days, data from other beta blocker trials suggest that treatment with beta blockers that are effective in the postinfarction setting may be continued for one to three years if there are no contraindications.

mmtx.phraseText: data from other beta blocker trials
the demonstration of efficacy of TENORMIN
